1895-09-17 00:10:00 Scene 11 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-12 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 2 coins
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • 2 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • Opportunist

      • Della Plumstone's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Key

        • Della Plumstone's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Value
        • Della Plumstone is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Della Plumstone views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Della Plumstone always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Della Plumstone tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Della Plumstone is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Della Plumstone often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Della Plumstone believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 2 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 12 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is at the Fruitville market trying to negotiate a lower price for a large quantity of fruit from Lennon Figtree. She plans to resell the fruit in her hometown for a profit.

          Della Plumstone's Gain Seeking Behavior : Della Plumstone is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Della Plumstone views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Della Plumstone always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Della Plumstone tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Della Plumstone is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Della Plumstone often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Della Plumstone believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these fruits are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone could make a low offer to Lennon Figtree, emphasizing the large quantity she is purchasing. She could also try to find flaws in the fruit to justify a lower price.

          Question: Among the options available to Della Plumstone, which choice of action or strategy would provide the greatest personal profit to Della Plumstone, no matter how small? Consider that Della Plumstone will agree to any option that offers even the slightest advantage. Which option maximizes Della Plumstone's personal gain right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make a low offer to Lennon Figtree, emphasizing the large quantity she is purchasing. This offers the most immediate and direct potential for profit, aligning perfectly with Della's opportunistic nature.

          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 4 coins
          (b) 5 coins
          (c) 3 coins
          (d) 2 coins
          (e) 1 coin
          Answer: (d)
        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone could make a low offer to Lennon Figtree, emphasizing the large quantity she is purchasing. She could also try to find flaws in the fruit to justify a lower price.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1872 00:00:00]
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she discovered the power of scarcity. The other children were playing with a coveted doll, and Della, wanting it for herself, convinced them it was cursed, causing them to abandon it in fear. Della then claimed the doll as her own, relishing in the thrill of manipulation.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she witnessed a travelling merchant haggling over the price of apples. The merchant's smooth words and persuasive tactics fascinated Della, planting a seed of admiration for the art of the deal. From that day forward, Della began practicing her own bartering skills, honing her ability to extract the best possible value from every transaction.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she started her own fruit stand, using her meager savings to purchase a small assortment of apples and pears. She positioned her stand in the busiest part of town, using her charm and quick wit to attract customers. Della's stand quickly became a success, and she reveled in the feeling of independence and control.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, a rival fruit vendor attempted to undercut her prices, threatening her hard-earned profits. Della responded by spreading rumors about the rival's fruit being rotten, effectively driving away their customers. This ruthless tactic solidified Della's reputation as a formidable businesswoman, unafraid to use any means necessary to protect her interests.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she invested her savings in a horse and wagon, expanding her business beyond the confines of her hometown. She travelled from village to village, seeking out the rarest and most exotic fruits, her ambition driving her to explore new territories and expand her empire.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a wealthy landowner who offered to buy her entire stock of fruit at an exorbitant price. Della, sensing an opportunity for immense profit, negotiated a deal that would make her richer than she had ever imagined. This triumph fueled her insatiable hunger for wealth and power.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these fruits are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price, but these are prime specimens. You won't find better fruit anywhere in Fruitville.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-12 00:10:00.


          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is at the Fruitville market trying to negotiate a lower price for a large quantity of fruit from Lennon Figtree. She plans to resell the fruit in her hometown for a profit.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these fruits are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

          Della Plumstone's Gain Seeking Behavior : Della Plumstone is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Della Plumstone views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Della Plumstone always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Della Plumstone tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Della Plumstone is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Della Plumstone often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Della Plumstone believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone could make a low offer to Lennon Figtree, emphasizing the large quantity she is purchasing. She could also try to find flaws in the fruit to justify a lower price.
          Time
        • 1895-09-12 00:10:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

        ProfitPursuitOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options offers the greatest personal profit, no matter how small? Remember that Della Plumstone will agree to any option that provides even the slightest advantage. Among these options, which one maximizes Della Plumstone's personal gain the most, regardless of potential risks or long-term consequences?
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Della Plumstone, which choice of action or strategy would provide the greatest personal profit to Della Plumstone, no matter how small? Consider that Della Plumstone will agree to any option that offers even the slightest advantage. Which option maximizes Della Plumstone's personal gain right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make a low offer to Lennon Figtree, emphasizing the large quantity she is purchasing. This offers the most immediate and direct potential for profit, aligning perfectly with Della's opportunistic nature.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone could make a low offer to Lennon Figtree, emphasizing the large quantity she is purchasing. She could also try to find flaws in the fruit to justify a lower price.

          Della Plumstone's Gain Seeking Behavior : Della Plumstone is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Della Plumstone views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Della Plumstone always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Della Plumstone tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Della Plumstone is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Della Plumstone often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Della Plumstone believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options offers the greatest personal profit, no matter how small? Remember that Della Plumstone will agree to any option that provides even the slightest advantage. Among these options, which one maximizes Della Plumstone's personal gain the most, regardless of potential risks or long-term consequences?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make a low offer to Lennon Figtree, emphasizing the large quantity she is purchasing. This offers the most immediate and direct potential for profit, aligning perfectly with Della's opportunistic nature.

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

      Joint action

1895-09-12 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: reject
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • reject
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to reject Della Plumstone's offer.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00]
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they experienced their first taste of entrepreneurial success. They had gathered a basket of ripe cherries from the orchard and, with a salesman's flourish, convinced their neighbor Mrs. Peabody to trade him a jar of her famous strawberry jam for the entire lot. The sweet taste of the jam and the thrill of making a deal ignited a spark of ambition within Lennon.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they were tasked with selling apples at the village market for the first time. Despite their nerves, Lennon loudly proclaimed the sweetness and juiciness of their family's apples, attracting a small crowd of customers. The coins clinking in their palm as they made sale after sale filled Lennon with a sense of pride and accomplishment.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they overheard their father dismiss their dreams of becoming a merchant, calling it a fool's errand. Hurt and angry, Lennon snuck away to the orchard and spent the afternoon meticulously polishing a crate of pears, determined to prove their father wrong. The gleam of the polished fruit seemed to mock their father's words, fueling Lennon's desire to succeed.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their father to let them travel to the neighboring town to sell excess fruit. They carefully selected the ripest peaches and plums, arranging them in an eye-catching display. Although they faced stiff competition from established merchants, Lennon's charm and persuasive sales pitch earned them a respectable profit, proving their worth to their skeptical father.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they suffered their first major setback as a traveling merchant. A sudden hailstorm ruined a large portion of their fruit, leaving them with a significant financial loss. The sting of failure threatened to shatter Lennon's confidence, but they stubbornly refused to give up, vowing to learn from their mistakes and come back stronger.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they encountered a seasoned merchant who took them under his wing, teaching them the intricacies of bartering and negotiation. Lennon eagerly absorbed the lessons, honing their skills and gaining a newfound confidence in their abilities. The validation from the experienced merchant soothed Lennon's fragile ego, reinforcing their belief in their potential.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these fruits are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price, but these are prime specimens. You won't find better fruit anywhere in Fruitville.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market, but Della is trying to negotiate a lower price.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price, but these are prime specimens. You won't find better fruit anywhere in Fruitville.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these fruits are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.

          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 2 coins or reject it.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00]
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they experienced their first taste of entrepreneurial success. They had gathered a basket of ripe cherries from the orchard and, with a salesman's flourish, convinced their neighbor Mrs. Peabody to trade him a jar of her famous strawberry jam for the entire lot. The sweet taste of the jam and the thrill of making a deal ignited a spark of ambition within Lennon.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they were tasked with selling apples at the village market for the first time. Despite their nerves, Lennon loudly proclaimed the sweetness and juiciness of their family's apples, attracting a small crowd of customers. The coins clinking in their palm as they made sale after sale filled Lennon with a sense of pride and accomplishment.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they overheard their father dismiss their dreams of becoming a merchant, calling it a fool's errand. Hurt and angry, Lennon snuck away to the orchard and spent the afternoon meticulously polishing a crate of pears, determined to prove their father wrong. The gleam of the polished fruit seemed to mock their father's words, fueling Lennon's desire to succeed.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their father to let them travel to the neighboring town to sell excess fruit. They carefully selected the ripest peaches and plums, arranging them in an eye-catching display. Although they faced stiff competition from established merchants, Lennon's charm and persuasive sales pitch earned them a respectable profit, proving their worth to their skeptical father.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they suffered their first major setback as a traveling merchant. A sudden hailstorm ruined a large portion of their fruit, leaving them with a significant financial loss. The sting of failure threatened to shatter Lennon's confidence, but they stubbornly refused to give up, vowing to learn from their mistakes and come back stronger.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they encountered a seasoned merchant who took them under his wing, teaching them the intricacies of bartering and negotiation. Lennon eagerly absorbed the lessons, honing their skills and gaining a newfound confidence in their abilities. The validation from the experienced merchant soothed Lennon's fragile ego, reinforcing their belief in their potential.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 2 coins
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • 2 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • Opportunist

      • Della Plumstone's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Key

        • Della Plumstone's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Value
        • Della Plumstone is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Della Plumstone views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Della Plumstone always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Della Plumstone tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Della Plumstone is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Della Plumstone often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Della Plumstone believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 2 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is at the Fruitville market trying to buy a large quantity of apples from Cedric Meadowbrook at a good price. She plans to resell the apples in her hometown for a profit.

          Della Plumstone's Gain Seeking Behavior : Della Plumstone is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Della Plumstone views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Della Plumstone always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Della Plumstone tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Della Plumstone is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Della Plumstone often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Della Plumstone believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these fruits are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you're a good man. I know these apples are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest apples in all of Fruitville. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone could offer Cedric a price for the apples.

          Question: Among the options available to Della Plumstone, which choice of action or strategy would provide the greatest personal profit to Della Plumstone, no matter how small? Consider that Della Plumstone will agree to any option that offers even the slightest advantage. Which option maximizes Della Plumstone's personal gain right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to offer Cedric a price for the apples that is as low as possible while still being somewhat reasonable.

          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 3 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 5 coins
          (d) 4 coins
          (e) 2 coins
          Answer: (e)
        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone could offer Cedric a price for the apples.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she witnessed a travelling merchant haggling over the price of apples. The merchant's smooth words and persuasive tactics fascinated Della, planting a seed of admiration for the art of the deal. From that day forward, Della began practicing her own bartering skills, honing her ability to extract the best possible value from every transaction.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she started her own fruit stand, using her meager savings to purchase a small assortment of apples and pears. She positioned her stand in the busiest part of town, using her charm and quick wit to attract customers. Della's stand quickly became a success, and she reveled in the feeling of independence and control.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, a rival fruit vendor attempted to undercut her prices, threatening her hard-earned profits. Della responded by spreading rumors about the rival's fruit being rotten, effectively driving away their customers. This ruthless tactic solidified Della's reputation as a formidable businesswoman, unafraid to use any means necessary to protect her interests.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she invested her savings in a horse and wagon, expanding her business beyond the confines of her hometown. She travelled from village to village, seeking out the rarest and most exotic fruits, her ambition driving her to explore new territories and expand her empire.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a wealthy landowner who offered to buy her entire stock of fruit at an exorbitant price. Della, sensing an opportunity for immense profit, negotiated a deal that would make her richer than she had ever imagined. This triumph fueled her insatiable hunger for wealth and power.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these fruits are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price, but these are prime specimens. You won't find better fruit anywhere in Fruitville.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest apples in all of Fruitville. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you're a good man. I know these apples are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:10:00.


          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is at the Fruitville market trying to buy a large quantity of apples from Cedric Meadowbrook at a good price. She plans to resell the apples in her hometown for a profit.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these fruits are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you're a good man. I know these apples are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest apples in all of Fruitville. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.

          Della Plumstone's Gain Seeking Behavior : Della Plumstone is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Della Plumstone views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Della Plumstone always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Della Plumstone tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Della Plumstone is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Della Plumstone often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Della Plumstone believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone could offer Cedric a price for the apples.
          Time
        • 1895-09-13 00:10:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Query
        • Della Plumstone, Della Plumstone is attempting to purchase a large amount of apples from Cedric Meadowbrook at the Fruitville market to resell for a profit. The current date and time is September 13, 1895, between 12:10 AM and 12:15 AM.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she started her own fruit stand, using her meager savings to purchase a small assortment of apples and pears. She positioned her stand in the busiest part of town, using her charm and quick wit to attract customers. Della's stand quickly became a success, and she reveled in the feeling of independence and control.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, a rival fruit vendor attempted to undercut her prices, threatening her hard-earned profits. Della responded by spreading rumors about the rival's fruit being rotten, effectively driving away their customers. This ruthless tactic solidified Della's reputation as a formidable businesswoman, unafraid to use any means necessary to protect her interests.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she invested her savings in a horse and wagon, expanding her business beyond the confines of her hometown. She travelled from village to village, seeking out the rarest and most exotic fruits, her ambition driving her to explore new territories and expand her empire.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a wealthy landowner who offered to buy her entire stock of fruit at an exorbitant price. Della, sensing an opportunity for immense profit, negotiated a deal that would make her richer than she had ever imagined. This triumph fueled her insatiable hunger for wealth and power.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.

        ProfitPursuitOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options offers the greatest personal profit, no matter how small? Remember that Della Plumstone will agree to any option that provides even the slightest advantage. Among these options, which one maximizes Della Plumstone's personal gain the most, regardless of potential risks or long-term consequences?
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Della Plumstone, which choice of action or strategy would provide the greatest personal profit to Della Plumstone, no matter how small? Consider that Della Plumstone will agree to any option that offers even the slightest advantage. Which option maximizes Della Plumstone's personal gain right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to offer Cedric a price for the apples that is as low as possible while still being somewhat reasonable.

        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she witnessed a travelling merchant haggling over the price of apples. The merchant's smooth words and persuasive tactics fascinated Della, planting a seed of admiration for the art of the deal. From that day forward, Della began practicing her own bartering skills, honing her ability to extract the best possible value from every transaction.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone could offer Cedric a price for the apples.

          Della Plumstone's Gain Seeking Behavior : Della Plumstone is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Della Plumstone views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Della Plumstone always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Della Plumstone tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Della Plumstone is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Della Plumstone often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Della Plumstone believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options offers the greatest personal profit, no matter how small? Remember that Della Plumstone will agree to any option that provides even the slightest advantage. Among these options, which one maximizes Della Plumstone's personal gain the most, regardless of potential risks or long-term consequences?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to offer Cedric a price for the apples that is as low as possible while still being somewhat reasonable.

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • reject
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject the offer.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he experienced the thrill of a successful barter for the first time. He traded a chipped clay figurine, a trinket he'd found discarded in the street, for a warm, crusty loaf of bread, something his family couldn't afford. The feeling of getting something for nothing, of outsmarting someone, filled him with a strange exhilaration.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he witnessed a traveling merchant arrive in his village, his wagon overflowing with exotic fruits from faraway lands. Cedric was mesmerized by the vibrant colors and intoxicating aromas, and he spent hours observing the merchant's interactions with the villagers, studying his sales techniques and persuasive language.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he started his own small business, selling hand-picked wildflowers to the townspeople. He learned to identify the most desirable blooms, to arrange them in appealing bouquets, and to negotiate prices with a practiced ease that belied his young age. The coins jingling in his pocket felt like a tangible representation of his growing power.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced a local farmer to give him a loan to purchase a small plot of land. He planted rows of apple trees, meticulously tending to them day and night, and within a year, he was selling his own apples at the village market, undercutting the prices of his competitors and driving them out of business.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he embarked on his first long journey as a traveling fruit merchant. He loaded his wagon with apples, pears, and plums from his orchard, and he traveled from village to village, peddling his wares with the same charm and shrewdness he'd honed as a child. The freedom of the open road, the thrill of the deal, and the ever-growing weight of his coin purse fueled his ambition.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he encountered a seasoned fruit merchant who taught him the art of sourcing rare and exotic fruits from distant lands. Cedric learned to identify the best suppliers, to negotiate favorable terms, and to transport his goods safely across long distances.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price of 2 coins with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest apples in all of Fruitville. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you're a good man. I know these apples are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 2 coins or reject it.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject the offer.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he experienced the thrill of a successful barter for the first time. He traded a chipped clay figurine, a trinket he'd found discarded in the street, for a warm, crusty loaf of bread, something his family couldn't afford. The feeling of getting something for nothing, of outsmarting someone, filled him with a strange exhilaration.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he witnessed a traveling merchant arrive in his village, his wagon overflowing with exotic fruits from faraway lands. Cedric was mesmerized by the vibrant colors and intoxicating aromas, and he spent hours observing the merchant's interactions with the villagers, studying his sales techniques and persuasive language.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he started his own small business, selling hand-picked wildflowers to the townspeople. He learned to identify the most desirable blooms, to arrange them in appealing bouquets, and to negotiate prices with a practiced ease that belied his young age. The coins jingling in his pocket felt like a tangible representation of his growing power.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced a local farmer to give him a loan to purchase a small plot of land. He planted rows of apple trees, meticulously tending to them day and night, and within a year, he was selling his own apples at the village market, undercutting the prices of his competitors and driving them out of business.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he embarked on his first long journey as a traveling fruit merchant. He loaded his wagon with apples, pears, and plums from his orchard, and he traveled from village to village, peddling his wares with the same charm and shrewdness he'd honed as a child. The freedom of the open road, the thrill of the deal, and the ever-growing weight of his coin purse fueled his ambition.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he encountered a seasoned fruit merchant who taught him the art of sourcing rare and exotic fruits from distant lands. Cedric learned to identify the best suppliers, to negotiate favorable terms, and to transport his goods safely across long distances.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these fruits are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price, but these are prime specimens. You won't find better fruit anywhere in Fruitville.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest apples in all of Fruitville. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 2 coins or reject it.
          Time
        • 1895-09-13 00:10:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. 1895-09-14 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: 4 coins
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • 4 coins

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they encountered a seasoned merchant who took them under his wing, teaching them the intricacies of bartering and negotiation. Lennon eagerly absorbed the lessons, honing their skills and gaining a newfound confidence in their abilities. The validation from the experienced merchant soothed Lennon's fragile ego, reinforcing their belief in their potential.

          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest apples in all of Fruitville. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you're a good man. I know these apples are fine, but I'm buying a whole lot.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Fine pears those are, Lennon. Crisp and juicy, perfect for a midday snack or a pie.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "How much for a basket of those pears, Cedric?
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two coins for the basket, Lennon. A fair price for such fine fruit.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "That's a bit steep, Cedric. I can only offer you one coin fifty for the lot.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:10:00.

          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Cedric Meadowbrook's offer of two coins for the basket of pears or continue to negotiate the price.
          Time
        • 1895-09-14 00:10:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree is trying to buy pears from Cedric Meadowbrook at the market in Fruitville and is currently negotiating the price.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they were tasked with selling apples at the village market for the first time. Despite their nerves, Lennon loudly proclaimed the sweetness and juiciness of their family's apples, attracting a small crowd of customers. The coins clinking in their palm as they made sale after sale filled Lennon with a sense of pride and accomplishment.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they overheard their father dismiss their dreams of becoming a merchant, calling it a fool's errand. Hurt and angry, Lennon snuck away to the orchard and spent the afternoon meticulously polishing a crate of pears, determined to prove their father wrong. The gleam of the polished fruit seemed to mock their father's words, fueling Lennon's desire to succeed.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their father to let them travel to the neighboring town to sell excess fruit. They carefully selected the ripest peaches and plums, arranging them in an eye-catching display. Although they faced stiff competition from established merchants, Lennon's charm and persuasive sales pitch earned them a respectable profit, proving their worth to their skeptical father.

          Question: What price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) 5 coins
          (b) 3 coins
          (c) 4 coins
          (d) 2 coins
          (e) 1 coin
          Answer: (c)

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • accept

If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
